standard_metadata.standard_description: Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Area and circumference of circles challenge

question.content: The figure below shows a rope that circles the Earth. The radius of the Earth is $6371$ kilometers.    **Assuming the rope makes a perfect circle, what is the length of this rope?**   *Give your answer in terms of pi.*   kilometers

images.alt: Image of the Earth with the radius labeled as 6,371 kilometers and a circular outline around the Earth.

hints.content: The length of the rope is equal to the circumference of the Earth.  We can use the formula $\maroonD{C}=2\pi \blueD{r}$ to find the circumference of a circle with radius $\blueD{r}$.

The circumference of a circle with radius $\blueD{r}= \blueD{6371}\text{ km}$ is  $\begin{align}  \maroonD{C}  &=2\pi \blueD{r}  \\[2mm] &=2\pi (\blueD{6371}\text{ km}) \\[2mm] &= 12742\pi \text{ km} \end{align}$
The length of the rope is $12742\pi$ kilometers.

question.content: The penguin exhibit at a zoo has a raised circular island that is surrounded by water. The diameter of the island is  $20 \text{ meters}$.  One penguin swims half way around the island before hopping out.  ** How far did the penguin swim?**   *Give your answer in terms of pi.*  $$ meters

hints.content: The distance half way around the outside of the island is half the circumference.  We can use the formula $\maroonD{C}=\pi \blueD{d}$ to find the circumference, which is the total distance around the island.

The circumference of a circle with diameter of $\blueD{20}\text{ m}$ is:  $\begin{align} \maroonD{C}  &=\pi \blueD{d}  \\[2mm] &=\pi (\blueD{20}\text{ m}) \\[2mm] &= \blueD{20\pi} \text{ m} \end{align}$
To find the distance around half the island, we need to divide:  $\begin{align}\maroonD{C} &= \blueD{20 \pi}  \text{ m}\\ \\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{20 \pi }\text{ m}}{2}\\ \\ &=10 \pi\text{ m} \end{align}$
The penguin swam $10\pi$ meters.

question.content: You are standing next to a really big circular lake. You want to measure the diameter of the lake, but you don't want to have to swim across with a measuring tape! You decide to walk around the perimeter of the lake and measure its circumference, and find that it's $400\pi\text{ m}$.  **What is the diameter $d$ of the lake?**  $d=$   $\text{m}$

hints.content: This problem calls for the formula of the circumference of a circle $\blueD{C}=\pi \greenD{d}$.
You measured the circumference of the lake to be $\blueD{400\pi}\text{ m}$.

To find the diameter of the lake we must solve for $\greenD{d}$ in the following equation   $\begin{align*}   \pi \greenD{d} &= \blueD{C} \\[1mm] \pi \greenD{d} 	&= \blueD{400\pi}\text{ m} \\[1mm]   \cancel{\pi} \greenD{d} 	 &= 400\cancel{\pi}\text{ m} \\[1mm]    \greenD{d} &= 400\text{ m} \end{align*}$
The diameter of the lake is $400\text{ m}$.

question.content: A python curls up to touch the tip of its own tail with its nose, forming  the shape of a circle. The python is $2.6 \pi$ meters long.    **What is the radius $r$ of the circle that the python forms?**  $r=$   $\text{  m}$

hints.content: When the python curls to form the shape of a circle, the circumference of this circle is equal to the length of the python $\blueD{C}=\blueD{2.6\pi}\text{ m}$.

We know the formula for the circumference of a circle is $\blueD{C}=2\pi \maroonD{r}$.  If we want to find the radius of the circle formed by the python we must solve for $\maroonD{r}$ in the following equation:   $\begin{align*}   2\pi \maroonD{r} 	&= \blueD{2.6\pi}\text{ m} \\[1mm]    \maroonD{r}    &= \dfrac{ \blueD{2.6\pi} } { 2 \pi }\text{ m} \\    \maroonD{r}     	&= \maroonD{1.3}\text{ m} \end{align*}$
The radius of the circle formed by the python is $\maroonD{1.3}\text{ m}$.

question.content: The planet Neptune orbits the Sun. Its orbital radius is $30.1$ astronomical units $(\text{AU})$.  **Assuming Neptune's orbit is circular, what is the distance it travels in a single orbit around the Sun?**   *Give your answer in terms of $\pi$.*   $\text{AU}$

hints.content: The distance Neptune travels in a single orbit is equal to the circumference of its orbit.  We can use the formula $\blueD{C}=2\pi\maroonD{r}$ to find the circumference of a circle with radius $\maroonD{r}$.
The circumference of a circle with radius $\maroonD{r}=\maroonD{30.1} \text{ AU}$ is:  $\begin{align} \blueD{C}&=2\pi\maroonD{r} \\ &=2\pi(\maroonD{30.1}) \\ &=\blueD{60.2\pi} \end{align}$
The distance Neptune travels in a single orbit around the Sun is $\blueD{60.2\pi} \text{ AU}$.

question.content: The circumference of a hula hoop is $86\pi \text{ cm}$.  **What is the radius of the hula hoop?**   $\text{cm}$

hints.content: We can use the formula $\blueD{C}=2\pi\greenD{r}$ to find the radius of a circle with circumference $\blueD{C}$.

The circumference is $\blueD{86\pi} \text{ cm}$.  $\begin{align} 2\pi\greenD{r}&=\blueD{C} \\ 2\pi\greenD{r}&=\blueD{86\pi} \\ \greenD{r}&=\dfrac{\blueD{86\pi}}{2\pi} \\ \greenD{r}&=\greenD{43} \end{align}$
The radius of the hula hoop is $\greenD{43} \text{ cm}$.

question.content: A round cake has a diameter of $30\text{ cm}$. Angela places the cake on a circular cake board with a  diameter $5 \text{ cm}$ longer than that of the cake.  **What is the circumference of the cake board?**   *Give your answer in terms of $\pi$.*   $\text{cm}$

hints.content: We can use the formula $\blueD{C}=\pi\purpleC{d}$ to find the circumference of a circle with diameter $\purpleC{d}$.
The diameter of the cake board is $5 \text{ cm}$ longer than $30 \text{ cm}$.  $5+30=\purpleC{35}$   The diameter of the cake board is $\purpleC{35}\text{ cm}$.
$\begin{align} \blueD{C}&=\pi\purpleC{d} \\ \blueD{C}&=\pi(\purpleC{35}) \\ \blueD{C}&=\blueD{35\pi} \end{align}$
The circumference of the cake board is $\blueD{35\pi} \text{ cm}$.

question.content: An artist is creating a large butterfly sculpture outside a museum. There is a circular dot on each wing made out of a metal ring. The distance around each dot is $24 \pi \text{ inches}$.  The artist plans to fill the inside of each dot with blue colored glass.  **What is the area of the  blue glass will be needed to fill each butterfly dot?**   *Give your answer in terms of pi.*  $A=$   $\text{inches}^2$

hints.content: The artist knows the circumference of the circle and wants to find the area.   We need to use the formulas $\blueD{C}=2\pi \maroonD{r}$ and $\purpleD{A}=\pi \maroonD{r}^2$ to solve this problem.

The circumference of a circle with radius $\maroonD{r}$ is $\blueD{C}=2\pi \maroonD{r}$.  Since we know $\blueD{C}=\blueD{24\pi}\text{ inches}$, we can find $\maroonD{r}$ by dividing:  $\begin{align*}    2\pi \maroonD{r} 	&= \blueD{24\pi} \text{ inches}	\\[1mm]    \maroonD{r}     	&= \dfrac{ \blueD{24\pi} } { 2 \pi }  \\    \maroonD{r}     	&= \maroonD{12}\text{ inches} \end{align*}$

Now that we know the radius of the dot is $\maroonD{12}\text{ inches}$, we can find the area of the blue glass:   $\begin{align*}  \purpleD{A} 	& =\pi \maroonD{r}^2 					\\ & = \pi \left(\maroonD{ 12}\right)^2	\\ & = 144\pi \text{ inches}^2 \end{align*}$
Each butterfly dot will need $144\pi\text{ inches}^2$ of blue glass.

question.content: A baker uses a coffee mug with a diameter of $8\text{ cm}$  to cut out circular cookies from a big sheet of cookie dough.    **What is the area $A$ of each cookie?**   *Give your answer in terms of pi.*  $A=$  $\text{cm}^2$

hints.content: This problem calls for the formula for the area of a circle $\purpleD{A}=\pi \maroonD{r}^2$.

The cup has a circular shape and its diameter is $\greenD{8}\text{ cm}$.  The radius of the cup is   $\begin{align}\qquad \maroonD{r} &= \dfrac{\greenD{d}}{2}\\ \\ &= \dfrac{\greenD{8}\text{ cm}}{2}\\ \\ &=\maroonD{4}\text{ cm}\end{align}$  To find the area, we substitute the value $\maroonD{r} = \maroonD{4}\text{ cm}$ into the formula for the area of a circle.

Using the formula  $\purpleD{A}=\pi \red{r}^2$, we find the area of each cookie is  $\begin{align}  \purpleD{A} 	& =\pi \maroonD{r}^2 	\\   	& = \pi (\maroonD{4}\text{ cm})^2		\\   	& = \pi (\maroonD{4} \times \maroonD{4}) \text{ cm}^2		\\   	&= 16 \pi  \text{ cm}^2		 \end{align}$
The area of each cookie is  $16 \pi \text{ cm}^2$.

question.content: A table with a round top is cut in half so that it can be used against a wall. After it is cut, the edge along the wall is $6 \text{ feet}$.    **What is the area $A$ of the table after it is cut in half ?**   *Give your answer in terms of pi.*  $A=$  $\text{feet}^2$

hints.content: The area of the table before it is cut would use the formula for the area of a circle, $\purpleD{A}=\pi\maroonD{r}^2$. The area after the table is cut in half will be half of that.

First let's find the area of the whole table, before it was cut in half. The diameter of the circular table is $\green{6}\text{ feet}$.  The radius of the table is:  $\begin{align} \maroonD{r} &= \dfrac{\greenD{d}}{2}\\ \\ &= \dfrac{\greenD{6}\text{ ft}}{2}\\ \\ &=\maroonD{3}\text{ ft}\end{align}$  To find the area, we substitute the value $\maroonD{r} = \maroonD{3}\text{ ft}$ into the formula for the area of a circle.

Using the formula  $\purpleD{A}=\pi \maroonD{r}^2$, we find the area of the whole table first.  $\begin{align}  \purpleD{A} 	& =\pi \maroonD{r}^2 	\\   	& = \pi (\maroonD{3}\text{ ft})^2		\\   	& = \pi (\maroonD{3} \times \maroonD{3}) \text{ ft}^2		\\   	&= \purpleD{9 \pi}  \text{ ft}^2	 \end{align}$

The area of the whole circular table is $\purpleD{9 \pi}  \text{ ft}^2$. To find the area of the table after it was cut in half, we need to divide:  $\begin{align}\purpleD{A} &= \purpleD{9 \pi}  \text{ ft}^2\\ \\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD{9 \pi }\text{ ft}^2}{2}\\ \\ &=4.5 \pi\text{ ft} ^2\end{align}$
The area of the table after it is cut in half is  $4.5 \pi \text{ ft}^2$.

question.content: A park has a large circle painted in the middle of the playground area. The circle is divided into $4$ equal sections, and each section is painted a different color. The radius of the circle is  $10 \text{ meters}$.    **What is the area $A$ of each section of the circle?**   *Give your answer in terms of pi.*  $A=$  $\text{m}^2$

hints.content: This problem calls for the formula for the area of a circle $\purpleD{A}=\pi \maroonD{r}^2$.

Using the formula  $\purpleD{A}=\pi \maroonD{r}^2$, we can find the area of the whole circle first.  $\begin{align}  \purpleD{A} 	& =\pi \maroonD{r}^2 	\\   	& = \pi (\maroonD{10}\text{ m})^2		\\   	& = \pi (\maroonD{10} \times \maroonD{10}) \text{ m}^2		\\   	&= \purpleD{100 \pi}  \text{ m}^2	 \end{align}$

The area of the whole painted circle is $\purpleD{100 \pi}  \text{ m}^2$. To find the area of each section of the circle we need to divide:  $\begin{align}\purpleD{A} &= \purpleD{100 \pi}  \text{ m}^2\\ \\ &= \dfrac{\purpleD{100 \pi }\text{ m}^2}{4}\\ \\ &=25 \pi\text{ m}^2\end{align}$
The area of each section of the circle is  $25 \pi \text{ m}^2$.

question.content: A building engineer analyzes a concrete column with a circular cross section.  The circumference of the column is $18 \pi$ meters.   **What is the area $A$ of the cross section of the column?**   *Give your answer in terms of pi.*  $A =$  $\text{ m}^2$

hints.content: The cross section of the concrete column is a circle. The engineer knows the circumference of the circle and wants to find the area.   We need to use the formulas $\blueD{C}=2\pi \maroonD{r}$ and $\purpleD{A}=\pi \maroonD{r}^2$ to solve this problem.

The circumference of a circle with radius $\maroonD{r}$ is $\blueD{C}=2\pi \maroonD{r}$.  Since we know $\blueD{C}=\blueD{18\pi}\text{ m}$, we can find $\maroonD{r}$ by dividing:  $\begin{align*}    2\pi \maroonD{r} 	&= \blueD{18\pi} \text{ m}	\\[1mm]    \maroonD{r}     	&= \dfrac{ \blueD{18\pi} } { 2 \pi }  \\    \maroonD{r}     	&= \maroonD{9}\text{ m} \end{align*}$

Now that we know the radius of the column is $\maroonD{r}=\maroonD{9}\text{ m}$, we can find the area of its cross section:   $\begin{align*}  \purpleD{A} 	& =\pi \maroonD{r}^2 					\\ & = \pi \left(\maroonD{ 9}\right)^2	\\ & = 81\pi \text{ m}^2 \end{align*}$
The area of the cross section of the concrete column is $81\pi  \text{ m}^2$.

question.content: An engineer is planning a new water pipe installation. The circular pipe has a diameter of $d=20\text{ cm}$.  **What is the area $A$ of the circular cross section of this pipe?**   *Give your answer in terms of pi.*  $A =$  $\text{cm}^2$

hints.content: This problem calls for the formula for the area of a circle $\purpleD{A} = \pi \maroonD{r}^2$.

The diameter of the pipe is $\greenD{20}\text{ cm}$. Since the radius of a circle is half the length of the diameter, we can divide to find the radius:  $\begin{align} \maroonD{r}  &= \dfrac{\greenD{20}}{2}  \\\\ \maroonD{r}   &= \maroonD{10}\text{ cm} \end{align}$

We can now use the formula for the area of a circle $\purpleD{A} = \pi \maroonD{r}^2$ to calculate the area of the cross section of the pipe.     The area of a pipe with radius $\maroonD{r}=\maroonD{10}\text{ cm}$ is:  $\begin{align*}   \purpleD{A}  	&= \pi \maroonD{r}^2 				\\   		&= \pi (\maroonD{10})^2			\\   		&= \pi (100)		\\   		&= 100 \pi \text{ cm}^2 \end{align*}$
The area of the cross section of this pipe is $100\pi  \text{ cm}^2$.

question.content: The area of an extra large circular pizza from Gambino's Pizzeria is $484\pi \text{ cm}^2$.  **What is the diameter of an extra large pizza from Gambino's Pizzeria?**   $\text{cm}$

hints.content: We can use the formula $\redD{A}=\pi\greenD{r}^2$ to find the radius of a circle given the area $\redD{A}$.

The area of the pizza is $\redD{484\pi} \text{ cm}^2$.  $\begin{align} \pi\greenD{r}^2&=\redD{A} \\ \pi\greenD{r}^2&=\redD{484\pi} \\ \greenD{r}^2&=\dfrac{\redD{484\pi}}{\pi} \\ \greenD{r}^2&=484 \\ \greenD{r}&=\greenD{22} \end{align}$  The radius of the pizza is $\greenD{22}\text{ cm}$.
The diameter $\goldE{d}$ of a circle is twice as long as its radius $\greenD{r}$.  $\begin{align} \goldE{d}&=2\greenD{r} \\ \goldE{d}&=2(\greenD{22}) \\ \goldE{d}&=\goldE{44} \end{align}$
The diameter of the extra large pizza is $\goldE{44} \text{ cm}$.

question.content: A sumo wrestling ring is circular and has a circumference of $4.6\pi \text{ meters}$.   **What is the area $A$ of the sumo wrestling ring in square meters?**   *Give your answer in terms of $\pi$.*  $A=$  $\text{m}^2$

hints.content: We can use the formula $\blueD{C}=2\pi\greenD{r}$ to find the radius of a circle with circumference $\blueD{C}$.

The circumference is $\blueD{4.6\pi} \text{ m}$.  $\begin{align} 2\pi\greenD{r}&=\blueD{C} \\ 2\pi\greenD{r}&=\blueD{4.6\pi} \\ \greenD{r}&=\dfrac{\blueD{4.6\pi}}{2\pi} \\ \greenD{r}&=\greenD{2.3} \end{align}$  The radius of the sumo ring is $\greenD{2.3} \text{ m}$.
Now, we can use the formula $\purpleC{A}=\pi\greenD{r}^2$ to find the area of a circle with radius $\greenD{r}$.
The radius is $\greenD{2.3} \text{ m}$.  $\begin{align} \purpleC{A}&=\pi\greenD{r}^2 \\ \purpleC{A}&=\pi(\greenD{2.3})^2 \\ \purpleC{A}&=\purpleC{5.29\pi}  \end{align}$
The area of the sumo wrestling ring is $\purpleC{5.29\pi} \text{ m}^2$.
